Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of Advanced Triaxial Testing Device for Comprehensive Characterization of Unsaturated and Expansive Soil Behaviors over a Wider Range of Soil Suction States

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant provides funding for the development of advanced triaxial testing device for comprehensive characterization of unsaturated and expansive soil behaviors over a wider range of soil suction states. Most of the expansive soils in the ground are in unsaturated state. Current geotechnical characterization uses simple tests that do not fully simulate mechanical response of soils in unsaturated state. Civil infrastructure damage and repair costs on these soils are millions of dollars annually and most of these are attributed to this poor characterization. With the 2010 NSF-MRI equipment development award, the interdisciplinary research team comprising of faculty from Geotechnical, Earth Sciences, and Electrical Engineering departments of the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) will work towards the development of an advanced triaxial testing device which will be used to provide better characterization of unsaturated and expansive soils over a wider range of soil suction states transpired in the field. Such characterization would lead to a better civil infrastructure design on unsaturated soils. The research team including faculty participants and doctoral as well as undergraduate students will participate in tasks comprising of design and development of suction controlling capabilities and automation tasks of testing operations. Researchers will work on both initial calibration and then validation of the unit by performing characterization studies on local expansive soils.

The broader impacts of this project include strengthening of fundamental understanding of volume change and strength behaviors of unsaturated expansive soils; offering educational training of skilled graduate and undergraduate students with instrumentation and data acquisition backgrounds; developing teaching modules for high school teachers involved in Science and Mathematics classes; presenting MRI work to K-12 students to enhance their interests in engineering and sciences; and disseminating of the research findings in major conferences and peer reviewed journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The complete characterization of unsaturated soils is currently limited and could be attributed to a lack of advanced material testing equipment that could be utilized to perform mechanical testing of these soils over a wide range of soil suction conditions. Collective efforts of a research team at the University of Texas at Arlington were aimed at developing a custom-designed triaxial test setup that combines two techniques that allow for low to high suction-controlled environments. The newly developed test device with the novel and advanced features was used to test unsaturated soil specimens in both static and repeated load environments under different suction conditions.

The performance of the triaxial set up was thoroughly checked for proper functioning, operation and testing capabilities, including compatibility of its process control software and data acquisition system. The device was further validated for providing repeatable test results of similar soil specimens. With the novel and advanced features, the system facilitated research investigations related to characterization of strength and stiffness behaviors of saturated and unsaturated soils comprising of silty sand and silt under varying matric suctions. Test results were analyzed to address the effects of soil suction on the measured soil properties. 

The custom-designed relative humidity (RH) chamber, along with an in-house fabricated Plexiglas chamber, was used to assess the soil water characteristic curve (SWCC) of the test soil over a high range of total suction. The same RH chamber was further integrated with the triaxial testing system. A series of triaxial tests were performed at higher values of total suction conditions. Test results were evaluated for repeatability and reliability as well as to understand the effects of high suction on soil strength parameters. Volume change response of the results are also analyzed and addressed.

Suction controlled multistage triaxial tests conducted on saturated and unsaturated compacted silty soil specimens demonstrated the ability of the device to provide peak shear strength under drained conditions. These results showed that the peak strength obtained from both conventional and multistage tests are close to each other signifying the importance of multistage tests on silty soils to provide drained parameters in a short time frame.

The hydro-mechanical response observed from the experimental series performed under controlled matric suction conditions was used to predict shear strength response of silty sand at critical state using the Barcelona Basic Model (BBM). The constitutive equations proposed in the model were calibrated to obtain the best fitting parameters using test results obtained from a low to medium matric suction range. The experimental results were compared with BBM predictions which showed a good agreement between these results.   

Analysis of the results from cyclic triaxial tests under undrained conditions on silty sand revealed that soil specimens at 95% saturation are also susceptible to liquefaction. As the soil starts to desaturate, the liquefaction resistance has increased rapidly. Samples tested at degree of saturation between 75% and 90% close to low levels of suction exhibited a strength reduction, but no liquefaction was recorded.

The triaxial setup was also employed to perform repeated load triaxial tests on subgrade cohesive soils to determine resilient modulus parameter. Based on suction controlled resilient modulus tests it can be mentioned that resilient modulus of silty soils increases with an increase in soil suction (close to drier conditions).

The outcomes from all these static and cyclic studies on unsaturated soils over a wide range of soil suction will significantly advance our understanding of static and cyclic loading responses of unsaturated soils and will further enhance current design practices on unsaturated soils.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The complete characterization of unsaturated soils is currently limited and could be attributed to a lack of advanced material testing equipment that could be utilized to perform mechanical testing of these soils over a wide range of soil suction conditions. Collective efforts of a research team at the University of Texas at Arlington were aimed at developing a custom-designed triaxial test setup that combines two techniques that allow for low to high suction-controlled environments. The newly developed test device with the novel and advanced features was used to test unsaturated soil specimens in both static and repeated load environments under different suction conditions. The device was further validated for providing repeatable test results of similar soil specimens. With the novel and advanced features, the system facilitated research investigations related to characterization of strength and stiffness behaviors of saturated and unsaturated soils comprising of silty sand and silt under varying matric suctions. Test results were analyzed to address the effects of soil suction on the measured soil properties. The custom-designed relative humidity (RH) chamber, along with an in-house fabricated Plexiglas chamber, was used to assess the soil water characteristic curve (SWCC) of the test soil over a high range of total suction. The same RH chamber was further integrated with the triaxial testing system. A series of triaxial tests were performed at higher values of total suction conditions. Test results were evaluated for repeatability and reliability as well as to understand the effects of high suction on soil strength parameters. Volume change response of the results are also analyzed and addressed. Samples tested at degree of saturation between 75% and 90% close to low levels of suction exhibited a strength reduction, but no liquefaction was recorded. The triaxial setup was also employed to perform repeated load triaxial tests on subgrade cohesive soils to determine resilient modulus parameter. Based on suction controlled resilient modulus tests it can be mentioned that resilient modulus of silty soils increases with an increase in soil suction (close to drier conditions). The outcomes from all these static and cyclic studies on unsaturated soils over a wide range of soil suction will significantly advance our understanding of static and cyclic loading responses of unsaturated soils and will further enhance current design practices on unsaturated soils.
